qas.question: What is the essential difference in radio waves transmitted by an antenna?
How can this be adjusted more easily than changing antenna types?
When might the size of an antenna cause an issue?
There is a relationship between the size of the antenna and the size of the wavelength with what antenna type?
What size antenna would not be good when the antenna needs to be directional?

context: An antenna transmits and receives radio waves with a particular <a0_0>polarization<a0_0/> which can be reoriented by <a1_0>tilting the axis<a1_0/> of the antenna in many (but not all) cases. The physical size of an antenna is often a practical issue, particularly <a2_0>at lower frequencies<a2_0/> (longer wavelengths). <a3_0>Highly directional<a3_0/> antennas need to be significantly larger than the wavelength. Resonant antennas usually use a linear conductor (or element), or pair of such elements, each of which is about a quarter of the wavelength in length (an odd multiple of quarter wavelengths will also be resonant). Antennas that are required to be <a4_0>small<a4_0/> compared to the wavelength sacrifice efficiency and cannot be very directional. Fortunately at higher frequencies (UHF, microwaves) trading off performance to obtain a smaller physical size is usually not required.
